page.title: 03FROM STONE AGE TO OUR AGE
page.content: This land has been occupied for about 5000 years. First came the primitive stone age tribes who have left us their worked flints which appear when the fields are ploughed - we thought they were rare creatures but it seems as though they occupied every south facing site near water. Then in the first or second century BC came the tribes who worked the iron, easily accessible in the clay soil.Rivers and streams here run red and rusty with the iron. These men made clumsy iron implements and weapons - they had to heat the iron again and again to get rid of the slag. The iron people began to clear the forests and carve out small damp and cold fields leaving trees round the edges to form boundaries. Bodle Street grew up like Topsy, people settling on the waste- land at the boundary of two manors.
